predictions.text: The published FOMC minutes for the March 2026 meeting will contain the word “tariff” at least 5 times (case-insensitive), by 2026-04-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Retrieve the official Federal Reserve PDF/HTML of the March 2026 FOMC minutes and count occurrences of the substring “tariff” (case-insensitive). Prediction resolves YES if count ≥ 5.
evidence: Fed Beige Book: businesses increasingly pass tariff-related costs to consumers, raising near-term inflation risks and complicating disinflation. https://www.marketwatch.com/story/businesses-across-the-country-are-starting-to-pass-along-higher-costs-from-tariffs-feds-beige-book-finds-f5bfd0df
monitoring_signals: Fed speakers explicitly citing tariffs as an inflation driver
FOMC statement language referencing trade policy/tariffs
Inflation breakevens rising on tariff headlines
predictions.rationale: Tariffs are becoming a commonly cited input-cost driver; minutes tend to mirror prominent risks discussed across districts.

predictions.text: In at least one BLS PPI release covering reference months Jan–Jun 2026, the seasonally adjusted Final Demand Goods index will rise by at least +0.7% month-over-month, by 2026-07-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Using BLS PPI tables for each monthly release (reference months Jan–Jun 2026), identify the SA m/m percent change for Final Demand Goods. YES if any month is ≥ +0.7%.
evidence: U.S. PPI rose 0.2% in November; goods +0.9% while services were flat, suggesting goods-led pipeline inflation pressure. https://www.bls.gov/news.release/archives/ppi_01142026.htm

Fed Beige Book: businesses increasingly pass tariff-related costs to consumers, raising near-term inflation risks and complicating disinflation. https://www.marketwatch.com/story/businesses-across-the-country-are-starting-to-pass-along-higher-costs-from-tariffs-feds-beige-book-finds-f5bfd0df
monitoring_signals: PPI goods subcomponents (energy, core goods) accelerating
Import price index and freight/shipping costs
Corporate earnings commentary on input-cost increases
predictions.rationale: Recent PPI data show goods can spike; tariff pass-through increases odds of another outsized monthly goods print.

predictions.text: The U.S. 10-year Treasury yield (FRED series DGS10) will close below 3.50% on at least one U.S. trading day, by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Check daily DGS10 values (or an equivalent official close series). YES if any date through 2026-06-30 has a value < 3.50.
evidence: Wholesale inflation was softer than expected while retail sales moved higher, signaling resilient demand with easing price pressures. https://www.cnbc.com/2026/01/14/wholesale-inflation-was-softer-than-expected-retail-sales-moved-higher-in-november.html

BEA’s Q3 2025 international transactions data spotlight the current-account balance and cross-border capital flows, key to dollar funding conditions. https://www.bea.gov/news/2026/us-international-transactions-3rd-quarter-2025
monitoring_signals: CPI/PCE downside surprises and falling inflation swaps
Deterioration in labor-market indicators (claims, payrolls)
Risk-off episodes driving duration demand
predictions.rationale: A modest growth scare or disinflation continuation could pull 10Y yields below mid-3s even if policy cuts are uncertain.

predictions.text: NAR Existing Home Sales (seasonally adjusted annual rate) will print at or above 4.50 million in at least one monthly release for reference months through 2026-05, by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Using National Association of Realtors monthly Existing Home Sales releases, resolve YES if any SAAR value reported for releases with reference months up to May 2026 is ≥ 4.50 million.
evidence: Existing home sales beat expectations to end 2025; prices eased further, pointing to improving transaction volumes despite still-high borrowing costs. https://www.cnbc.com/2026/01/14/existing-home-sales-end-2025-stronger-than-expected.html
monitoring_signals: Mortgage rate declines and purchase application trends
Inventory levels and months’ supply
Homebuilder sentiment and housing starts
predictions.rationale: Transaction volumes appear to be recovering from depressed levels; modest rate relief and easing prices can lift SAAR above 4.5M.

predictions.text: BLS will report the U.S. unemployment rate (U-3, seasonally adjusted) at or above 4.3% in at least one Employment Situation report released by 2026-07-10 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Check each monthly BLS Employment Situation release through the one published by 2026-07-10. YES if any reported U-3 unemployment rate is ≥ 4.3%.
evidence: U.S. retail sales strengthened in November while wholesale inflation was softer than expected, signaling resilient demand with easing price pressures. https://www.cnbc.com/2026/01/14/wholesale-inflation-was-softer-than-expected-retail-sales-moved-higher-in-november.html
monitoring_signals: Initial and continuing jobless claims trend
JOLTS openings and quits rate
Temporary help employment and hours worked
predictions.rationale: A mild cooling in hiring could lift unemployment modestly; 4.3% is a moderate threshold relative to late-cycle dynamics.

predictions.text: U.S. Commerce (BIS) will publish a Federal Register notice that proposes or implements an explicit licensing surcharge/fee mechanism (percentage or dollar fee) for exports of advanced AI chips to China, by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolve YES if a Federal Register document from BIS/Commerce explicitly establishes or proposes a fee/surcharge tied to licensing/export authorization for advanced AI chips to China (must include a numeric fee or formula).
evidence: Trump administration cleared Nvidia H200 chip sales to China with a 25% surcharge, signaling a more transactional approach to AI export controls. https://www.cnbc.com/2026/01/14/trump-nvidia-h200-china-ai-chips.html
monitoring_signals: Commerce/BIS press briefings about ‘fees’ or ‘surcharges’
Congressional letters/hearings on monetizing export licenses
Major chipmakers disclosing new China export terms
predictions.rationale: If the policy direction is toward transactional export controls, formalizing a surcharge mechanism is a plausible next step, but legal/process hurdles keep probability moderate.

predictions.text: OpenAI (or Microsoft on OpenAI’s behalf) will publicly announce a new compute procurement agreement with a non-Nvidia accelerator provider (e.g., Cerebras, AMD, Intel, Groq) with stated total contract value of at least $5.0B (USD), by 2026-09-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolve YES if OpenAI or Microsoft publicly announces a compute/chip supply or capacity deal naming a non-Nvidia accelerator provider and explicitly states total value ≥ $5.0B (or clearly equivalent multi-year committed spend).
evidence: OpenAI reportedly signed a ~$10B compute deal with Cerebras, underscoring escalating AI infrastructure spending and competition for specialized chips. https://techcrunch.com/2026/01/14/openai-signs-deal-reportedly-worth-10-billion-for-compute-from-cerebras/
monitoring_signals: Announcements of large-scale inference partnerships beyond Nvidia
Foundry capacity reservations and long-term wafer agreements
OpenAI/Microsoft disclosures about diversifying accelerator stack
predictions.rationale: Spending is escalating and diversification incentives are strong, but public disclosure with explicit ≥$5B value is less common.

predictions.text: California’s Department of Justice / Attorney General will publicly confirm issuance of a subpoena, civil investigative demand, or equivalent compulsory process to xAI related to Grok image generation (sexualized real-person or similar), by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolve YES if CA DOJ/AG or xAI publicly states that a subpoena/CID/compulsory legal demand was issued/served in the investigation, or if such a document is published by the AG/DOJ.
evidence: xAI disabled Grok’s sexualized real-person image generation amid backlash; California DOJ probe highlights rising regulatory and liability risk for generative AI. https://www.cnbc.com/2026/01/14/elon-musk-xai-california-grok-investigation.html
monitoring_signals: Public statements by CA AG about the status/escalation of the probe
xAI legal filings or transparency reports referencing government demands
New complaints from victims/advocacy groups prompting enforcement
predictions.rationale: A probe often escalates to compulsory process if voluntary cooperation is insufficient; timing uncertainty keeps confidence below 50%.

predictions.text: OFAC will issue a new or amended Venezuela-related General License that explicitly authorizes U.S. persons to engage in expanded transactions involving Venezuelan crude oil production and/or exports (beyond prior baseline authorizations), by 2026-05-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolve YES if OFAC publishes a Venezuela-related General License (new or amended) that explicitly authorizes broader crude production/export transactions than previously authorized (must reference crude oil and production/export activity).
evidence: U.S. seeks expanded Venezuelan oil dealings, reshaping ties; Senate vote blocked a Venezuela war-powers check, preserving executive flexibility. https://www.nytimes.com/2026/01/14/world/americas/venezuela-oil-us-deal.html
monitoring_signals: OFAC FAQ updates and GL amendments referencing PDVSA/crude exports
U.S. diplomatic statements on energy supply and Venezuela
IOC/refiner statements about seeking/receiving U.S. authorization
predictions.rationale: Reported policy direction points toward more Venezuelan oil engagement, but domestic politics and sanctions leverage make near-term license expansion uncertain.

predictions.text: The IAEA Board of Governors will adopt a resolution that formally censures Iran (or finds Iran in non-compliance) regarding safeguards/enrichment cooperation, by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolve YES if the IAEA Board of Governors adopts a resolution (reported by IAEA release or major wire services) that includes censure/non-compliance language regarding Iran’s safeguards or cooperation obligations.
evidence: U.S.-Iran tensions: personnel moved from Qatar base; Gulf allies oppose strikes; oil fell on hints of delay—risk premium remains headline-driven. https://www.cnbc.com/2026/01/14/oil-falls-nearly-2percent-after-trump-signals-he-could-hold-off-on-attacking-iran.html
monitoring_signals: IAEA Director General reports on Iran cooperation levels
European (E3) diplomatic positioning before Board meetings
Public references to referral/escalation steps
predictions.rationale: Heightened tensions increase the chance of diplomatic escalation via the IAEA, but member-state bargaining and timing make this less than even odds.
